description.narrative: PEA knowledge exchange and south-south cooperation. This output focuses on enhancing the spread (in support of the Poverty-Environment Action broadening strategy) and effectiveness (in support of PEA Outputs 1 and 2) of poverty-environment mainstreaming.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

comment.narrative: • Number of Poverty-Environment Action knowledge-sharing and learning products that are referenced by regional and global networks. Target: 23 • Number of countries adopting Poverty-Environment Action tools/approaches resulting from South-South knowledge collaboration. Target: 7 • Number of regional and global Poverty-Environment Action partner programmes and agencies that apply an integrated mainstreaming approach. Target: 7

- 20 Poverty-Environment Action knowledge-sharing and learning products referenced by regional and global networks. - 6 countries adopted Poverty-Environment Action tools/approaches resulting from South-South knowledge collaboration. - 6 regional and global Poverty-Environment Action partner programmes and agencies applied an integrated mainstreaming approach.

PEA advocates and coordinates with development partners engaged in supporting SDG implementation to mainstream the use of Poverty-Environment Action integrated approaches and tools in their programmes

Under this output, PEA focuses on enhancing the spread (in support of the Poverty-Environment Action broadening strategy) and effectiveness (in support of Outputs 1 and 2) of poverty-environment mainstreaming by better capturing, assessing and documenting good practices, by linking with ongoing work of key global and regional actors supporting national SDG implementation and acceleration processes (e.g. national SDG platforms, regional SDG knowledge exchanges), and through South-South cooperation. In 2019, this was done through the participation in the following meetings and cooperation with the following initiatives:
Poverty-Environment Action at the United Nations High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF) in New York, USA. In response to the global climate and ecological emergency, leading global labour, economic and environment institutions came together to commit to new principles to achieve green and fair economies at the side event Fast, Fair and Green Transformative Partnerships for an Inclusive Green Economy which was held on 16 July 2019 during the United Nations High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF) in New York, USA. The diverse institutions are calling for a different approach to governing economies that puts people and nature first. Poverty-Environment Action, together with other global institutions, launched a new framework for economic reform ― ‘Principles, priorities and pathways for inclusive green economies: Economic transformation to deliver the SDGs’ ― comprising a series of catalytic activities and key principles to guide collective action in diverse contexts. The collaborating institutions are: • Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI) • Green Economy Coalition • Green Growth Knowledge Partnership (GGKP) • International Labour Organisation (ILO) • Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) • United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) • United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) • UN Partnership for Action on Green Economy (PAGE) • UNDP-UNEP Poverty-Environment Action for Sustainable Development Goals (Poverty-Environment Action) • Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ)
Poverty-Environment Nexus Resolution adopted at UNEA4 The Resolution on the Poverty-Environment Nexus (UNEP/EA.4/RES.18) calls upon Member States to apply integrated, innovative and coherent approaches in developing and implementing policies, laws, plans and budgets on poverty eradication through sustainable environment and natural resources management. The resolution notes “with appreciation existing partnerships, including the joint United Nations Development Programme–United Nations Environment Programme Poverty-Environment Action for Sustainable Development Goals”. Poverty-Environment Action provided technical support to the drafting of the Poverty-Environment Nexus resolution proposed by the African group, creating a common understanding of the interactions between poverty and environment for Member States’ engagement during the United Nations Environment Assembly. Isabell Kempf, co-Manager, Poverty-Environment Action, UNEP, highlighted the strong interest at the UN Environment Assembly in the link between environmental and social inclusion issues, evidenced by the Poverty-Environment Action programme having been invited to participate in five 2019 UN Environment Assembly side events on human rights, poverty and biodiversity themes.
PEA participated and shared its experience at the following meetings • 8 – 11 January: GEC and PAGE Ministerial Meeting where Poverty-Environment Action shared best practices on inclusion and discussed partnerships and the new investment focus. Main theme: Advancing Inclusive and Sustainable Economies. • 19 February: EU Parliamentary meeting where Poverty-Environment Action was invited to deliver a keynote speech on the Poverty-Environment nexus for SDGs in Europe, no social policy without environmental action. • 1 – 2 April: Inclusive Green economy institutional collaboration meeting hosted by GIZ in Germany where it was discussed how to work together with partner organisations at global and country level • 3 – 4 February: High-level Panel on the Impact of Climate Change on Displacement of Women during the 33rd pre-summit meeting on mainstreaming gender equality convened by the Gender is My Agenda Campaign (GIMAC). • Key Principles for Inclusive and Green Economic Transformation Isabell Kempf and Anne Juepner, Poverty-Environment Action co-managers, participated in the institutional collaboration meeting on Green Economy hosted by GIZ in Berlin on 1 and 2 April 2019. The meeting assessed how Green Economy work should link with other economic concepts such as circular, blue economy, and adopted a statement of key principles for inclusive and green economic transformation, which was presented at the side event during the 2019 High Level Political Forum in New York. In the principles paper, the Green Economy Platform elaborated on the following 5 Principles: The Wellbeing Principle — the economy enables all people to create and enjoy prosperity The Justice Principle — the economy promotes equity within and between generations The Planetary Boundaries Principle — the economy safeguards, restores and invests in nature The Efficiency and Sufficiency Principle — the economy is geared to sustainable production and consumption The Good Governance Principle — the economy is guided by integrated, accountable and resilient institutions Achieving the SDGs within Europe Isabell Kempf was invited by the Club of Rome to participate in the EU Parliament discussion on Achieving the SDGs within Europe: No Poverty Eradication without Environmental Action — The panel looked into the interface between environmental and social issues through testimonies, concrete examples of best practices and lessons learned. She presented lessons learned from Poverty-Environment Initiative to make poverty-environment mainstreaming successful, including the central role of ministries of finance and planning, the need for policy coherence and sustainable investment, and implementing policies at local level in order to involve people in the change process. Panel Discussion on Governance for a just transition to a Green Economy France, Germany, the UK and other countries are trying to transition to a green economy, with different degrees of popular support. The French experience and the yellow vests movement have shown that such a transition needs to be done in an integrated way that takes into account its economic, social and environmental dimensions. The panel discussion on governance for a just transition to a green economy was held on 21 February 2019 in the Global Governance Institute, UCL, London. The panel discussed what kind of governance, institutions and actors we need to make sure that such a transition is just and supported by citizens. The panel consisted of PEA and its partners from IIED and the Green Economy Coalition. Green Economy Transformation in Cooperation with PAGE Isabell Kempf, co-Manager, Poverty-Environment Action attended the Green Economy/Green Economy Partnership for Action on Green Economy (PAGE) Ministerial Conference in Capetown, South Africa, on 11–12 January 2019 where she made a presentation on inclusiveness of green economy transition based on the experience of the Poverty-Environment Initiative. In the Committee of Permanent Representatives (CPR), held in Nairobi in early January, South Africa officially had asked for support from UN Environment on Poverty-Environment linkages and the social inclusion dimension of their transition to a green economy. Poverty-Environment Action is in discussion with the joint UNEP, BMU and GIZ project “Green Economy Transformation in cooperation with PAGE — synergies between low emission paths and the SDGs” to explore opportunities in working with Poverty-Environment Action on potential support to South Africa.
Poverty-Environment Action Financial Training On 18 July 2019, the acting PEA Project Management Specialist and the PEA Finance Analyst conducted a virtual training on the financial management and implementation arrangements of PEA with over 25 participants from PEA project countries attending. All PEA countries were invited to participate, and with the exception of Rwanda and Mauritania, all countries were able to attend. The training presentations and further guidelines were also shared with everybody via email, to ensure that colleagues who were not able to participate, are able to access the PEA financial management training presentations and guidelines for future reference. The training was able to provide a detailed overview of rules, regulations and procedures specific to PEA and allowed the colleagues from participating countries to ask questions and provide feedback during this interactive session. The training was an important step towards ensuring that all participating PEA countries are up to date on PEA project specific procedures, based on signed donor agreements as well as the PEA project document and have the right information and tools available to successfully implement PEA. Poverty-Environment Action Global Retreat Poverty-Environment Action held its first annual global retreat in Nairobi on 18–19 March 2019. In the opening remarks, Susan Gardner, Director, Ecosystems Division, UNEP, highlighted the continuing demand for poverty-environment and climate mainstreaming services from Member States. Tim Scott, Senior Policy Advisor, UNDP, representing Ms. Adriana Dinu, Deputy Director, Bureau for Program and Policy Support, UNDP, warned that environmental degradation and growing demands for water, energy and infrastructure are breaching planetary boundaries. Among global challenges, land degradation and biological diversity are main challenges in addition to climate change. The retreat took place in a very constructive atmosphere and had the following results: A shared vision on the implementation of the new project; Review of the Poverty-Environment Initiative Final Evaluation, with a view to extracting key lessons for implementation of the new project; Clear roles and responsibilities of the Poverty-Environment Action global team; Discussion of (i) Technical Assistance project proposal to be presented to the Project Board, (ii) Outcome 3 Global component deliverables, (iii) Communications and Donor Visibility requirements; Clear key operational processes; Reviewed status of project partner

• Number of Poverty-Environment Action knowledge-sharing and learning products that are referenced by regional and global networks. Target: 15 • Number of countries adopting Poverty-Environment Action tools/approaches resulting from South-South knowledge collaboration. Target: 5 • Number of regional and global Poverty-Environment Action partner programmes and agencies that apply an integrated mainstreaming approach. Target: 3

• 20 Poverty-Environment Action tools and products have so far been referenced. Target achieved. • Technical assistance project between Indonesia and South Africa facilitated by GIZ and Poverty-Environment Action launched in June 2020. • 7 regional and global Poverty-Environment Action partner programmes and agencies applied an integrated mainstreaming approach. PEA has partnered with ADB on Blue Economy, GIZ and PAGE on Green Bonds, UN Women on Gender in Agriculture Green Economy Coalition at country and global level, including a call to action on Covid-19 recovery during World Environment Day 2020 (5 June) In Mozambique, the SUNRED team has incorporated lessons from the World Bank funded MozFIP agroforestry project implemented in the Zambezia province and managed by the National Fund for Sustainable Development (FNDS)

- 19 Poverty-Environment Action knowledge-sharing and learning products referenced by regional and global networks. - 8 countries adopt Poverty-Environment Action tools/approaches resulting from South-South knowledge collaboration. - 8 regional and global Poverty-Environment Action partner programmes and agencies apply an integrate mainstreaming approach.
